title: Sets and functions
description: Mathematical foundations for computer science, probability, and statistics.
author: Samuel S. Watson

intro.title: Intro
intro.html: Sets and functions are foundational to the study of mathematics and ubiquitous in quantitative disciplines, including statistics and data science. In this course we review the basics of sets, lists, and functions from a data perspective. These ideas will be useful for developing rigorous mathematical language for discussing randomness, and they will also be helpful precursors to several important data structures we'll develop in the programming course.

step-1.title: Step
step-1.html:
Sets

A simple grocery list is a real-life example of a set: the main utility afforded by the grocery list is to answer the query "here's an item in the store; is it on list?" Note that for purposes of answering this question, the order of the listed items on the grocery list doesn't matter, and repeating an entry is equivalent to having a single instance of that entry. This leads us to the definition of the term set.

step-2.title: Step
step-2.html:
Definition
A set is an unordered collection of objects. The objects in a set are called elements.

step-3.title: Step
step-3.html: The term object in this definition is deliberately vague. Sets may contain any kind of data: numbers, words, symbols, circles, squares, other sets, and many others.

step-7.title: Step
step-7.html: The set containing no elements is called the and is denoted or {}.

step-13.title: Step
step-13.html:
Exercise
Think of four pairs of real-world sets which satisfy a subset relationship. For example, the set of cars is a subset of the set of vehicles.

step-25.title: Step
step-25.html:
Exercise
Show that the set of all ordered pairs of positive integers is countably infinite.

step-27.html: The complement of the set of groceries in the cart with respect to the set of groceries on the list is a meaningful set because those are the items .

step-39.title: Step
step-39.html:
Intersection

You realize that you and your partner inadvertently both made grocery lists and went grocery shopping the same afternoon. You want to know the items on both lists, because .

step-55.title: Step
step-55.html:
Exercises

Exercise
Select the most appropriate set theory term for each of the following real-world scenarios.

  • You have a list of patients which have a particular risk factor and a second list of patients who have another risk factor. You want to identify the patients with both risk factors.
  • Your company is merging with another company and you want to combine your customer database with their customer database to get a collection of all of the customer records.
  • You have a table containing information about all of the Champions League goals this year, and you want to look at the ones which were not scored by Ronaldo.
  • You have 68 clients to call, and you want to split them among your four salespeople.

lists.title: Lists
lists.html: Sets are data containers with very little structure: you can check membership (and perform membership-checking-related operations like unions or complements), but that's all. We will define various other types of collections which provide additional structure.

functions.title: Functions
functions.html:
The grocery lists you make for yourself probably don't look quite like a set or a list, because the quickest way to indicate how many of each item to purchase is to make a separate column:

item
count
apple
3
bread
1
squash
3

step-64.title: Step
step-64.html: We have two sets here: the set of grocery items and the set of positive integers. For each element in the former set, we want to associate with it some element of the latter set.

step-65.title: Step
step-65.html: Note that this construction is asymmetric in the two sets: every grocery item should have exactly one number associated with it, while some positive integers will be omitted and others may be associated with multiple grocery items.

step-68.title: Step
step-68.html: Solution. The functions are unequal, since their codomains are not the same.

step-71.title: Step
step-71.html:
Exercise
Find the range of the function from {apple, bread, squash} to represented by the following table. It contains elements.

item
count
apple
3
bread
1
squash
3

step-76.title: Step
step-76.html:
Solution. The first statement is true; for example, consider the squaring function from the real number line to itself. The preimage of any set of negative numbers is empty.

The second statement is also true, since multiple input elements may map to the same codomain element.

step-80.title: Step
step-80.html:
Exercise
For each of the four combinations of injectivity and surjectivity, come up with a real-world function which has that property.

For example, the function from the set of ticket numbers for a commercial airplane flight to the set of passengers on the plane (the one which associates each ticket number with the passenger named on that ticket) is bijective.

step-81.title: Step
step-81.html:
Exercise
State a general relationship involving the terms restriction, image, and range.

step-102.title: Step
step-102.html: Congratulations! You've completed the Data Gymnasia Sets and Functions course.
